text: Patient: So let me ask you this here, doc. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Do people come out of that surgery? Doctor: Oh, yeah! They do! (Cell phone rings) Patient: Right. Doctor: But it’s a start. So, what does that tell us? It’s aggressive, but we know that about your cancer. But, if we don’t talk about surgery as an option, then we didn’t do right by you because you know that that’s a possibility. What’s the root of all that? Well, it’s your cancer not controlled. That’s always the root of all evil. Not your bones, but your lymph nodes are growing. So, in this – Patient: So what’s goin’ on, so what’s goin’ on with my bones? Doctor: Nothin’. text: Family Member: Oh that’s not too bad. Doctor: Yeah it’s not too bad. And the pill you take, there's a funky schedule but normally it's like, twice a day. But not every day. And there's a set schedule. You don't have to be here every day for that. But I think the follow up there is once every four weeks if I'm not wrong. Family Member: The pill isn't in the container? He has to come down here? Doctor: Well, we give it to you. But it's a funky formulation where, because you know, we do an oral formulation of the chemo is a challenge. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So this is like, there's a loading dose and then you have a little bit of another dose. So it's like, it's a pharma-pharmaco kinetics dream, who thought about it, which is not like a doctor dream, which is like, “just give me the pill in my pocket once a day.” I think eventually they're going to do that. But there is a funky schedule to it. None of which you have to be here, you know, the entire time. But I think in the first few- oh gosh, the first few days I think that you're here maybe for the first week every day. So, but I'll get the schedule right, but once you get on a flow, you're not here every day. Not even close. So it’s either once every three weeks, or once every four weeks. Patient: I can do it because obviously the Xtandi has run its course. Family Member: You don't know yet if you want to do the trial. Patient: If I do the trial. I take what they give me. Family Member: Oh, that's right. Doctor: Yeah there's no choice there. Family Member: So if he wants to go somewhere, what’s the longest period of time he can be gone? Doctor: Oh. Well, probably three or four weeks

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Or in your case, you haven’t really been on a full dose, and you’ve had these interruptions where you’ve been, you know, totally off of it for three weeks, you know? And now for another two weeks. So. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: So when he comes back on September fifth, the two-hundred milligrams will be here, so he can take it with him that day? Doctor: Yes. That’s the plan. Provided that the hemoglobin is sufficient. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Right. Okay. So then if the hemoglobin is not sufficient when he comes back, for example, he gets the transfusion, he gets here, and do the lab or something, so if it’s not, then what happens? Doctor: Uh, I mean, I’ll have to look at the protocol to see, you know, what the rules are about how long the drug can be delayed. But one option would be to call it quits at that point in time and talk about additional therapies, new therapies. The second option would be to keep him off the drug for the maximum amount of time before the study, you know, would kick him out, and then to hope and pray and, and maybe even give another transfusion to make the hemoglobin. If you’re trying that hard to make the hemoglobin not drop, it probably means that it’s not in the best interest of the patient to stay on the study. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So let’s cross that bridge if we get to it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, but it will not be a very good sign if despite coming off the drug and the transfusion, the hemoglobin still drops. So after that point, we have a more detailed discussion about alternative options. Patient: Yes.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’ve amended it and added a new cohort, so another group of men. But, these are men that they’re last therapy, or their willingness to stay on Enzalutamide, because there’s one group, uh, that showed that maybe if you use Enzalutamide and immune therapy, you get a better response (chuckles) Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’re testing a group of men, uh, uh, with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Is that just starting? Doctor: Uh, that has been open probably for a couple of months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it has a lot of rules. Either, you have to be AR-V7 positive. So, we would have to draw a tube of blood. Uh, and that we can do. Uh, it takes a week to come back. You know, if prostate cancer went in there, that would be a possible reason why it would bleed. Um. Sometimes the adrenal gland just doesn’t get a good blood supply, and it does bleed. text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -and it was two something before. So with that rise, I got a little worried. Because I don't want the Xtandi to get away from us. At that point, there was a study and there still is, where people on Xtandi if they start to do this with their PSA, might be eligible to add another pill right on to that. So you still stay on Xtandi. But this other pill might make the Xtandi sort of work better. And, you know, if you were on full dose, you'd be eligible, if you were on three pills, as well as just the two pills a day is still an option. So initially, we weren't sure if it was going to open because this was a study that had a sugar pill arm that I wasn't too keen on. But with this new, kind of like update, everybody gets the pill. So this is where the study is. So here you are in your Xtandi. Xtandi, Xtandi, Xtandi. And then you get randomized. So flip of a coin to either get this new medicine at a certain dose, or this new medicine at the same dose. Okay, so so far, both arms are the same, you just get a new medicine at the same dose, okay, no placebo. This arm is going to keep you like that, so you take the Xtandi plus the new pill at the new dose, no problem, you're just on that. This arm is you on Xtandi plus the new pill, but every month, they're going to try to increase that dose gently. So you get another pill that has more milligrams in it. While that's happening, if you were on this arm, you get a matching placebo. So you do get a sugar pill, but that's in addition to the new pill already being on board. You still with me? Patient: No, you gotta slow down. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to say it again? Patient: Try me again. Doctor: Okay, no worries. Okay, here's you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: “Hello, I’m Mr. P___ I'm on two of Xtandi”. Patient: Yes. Doctor: PSA is starting to do this, uh-oh, we're kind of worried. So, sometimes the cancer gets smart. And now we say look, maybe there's a way to kind of flap that, see if we can get it to work again, because it did work for a while, which was good. So this pill going right along, we want to add a second pill. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: This study is to add a second pill, different pathway, to say hey, I'm gonna see if I add the second guy whether both together will make your PSA drop. But of course, to make things complicated, the second pill, they want to do stuff too. So they're going to have two groups. So if you're in the first group, you keep going on your Xtandi, and you get the second pill at a particular dose, no problem. Then W____ is on the same study, he's on Xtandi two pills a day. And I give him also the second pill at the same dose. Nobody's placebo-ing, you're now on two potentially active medicines, okay. But to make the study even more interesting, what they're doing is, if you are doing okay, on those two doses, they're going to give you an extra, you know, like 40 milligrams every month to see if they can increase that dose to get better mileage on this activity. But W____ is going to also get a matching pill. But his is not an active 40 milligrams, he just gets the sugar version of the 40 milligrams. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the reason I’m mentioning that is because a lot of patients do want to go on this therapy without being on the Lupron at the same time or a similar drug. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And the way that the trial is designed, if you give the testosterone without concurrently at the same time, suppressing the testosterone as well, then you don’t achieve these opposites between very high and very low levels. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: What happens is over time is the testosterone just keeps increasing and increasing and increasing, and eventually it will begin to feed the cancer, at least in theory. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So that is why we give both drugs in combination. And what happens is on a monthly basis through about twenty-eight day treatment cycles the testosterone goes from being super-high, much higher than your body would be able to make on its own back down to super-low. PAT Uh huh. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So every twenty-eight days which is roughly every four weeks, your testosterone will spike for a few days and then within about a week it will drop down to the very low levels. Patient: When you say spike, what numbers have you seen? Doctor: Right, so I told you before that a real low testosterone level for someone your age might be let’s say a hundred fifty to two hundred milligrams per deciliter. Here, they’re talking about between one thousand and one thousand five hundred milligrams per deciliter. So it’s a five- to ten-fold increase above the physiological level. So we call this super-physiological. That means higher than physiological.
conv5014_1-snip20.displayed_text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the reason I’m mentioning that is because a lot of patients do want to go on this therapy without being on the Lupron at the same time or a similar drug. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And the way that the trial is designed, if you give the testosterone without concurrently at the same time, suppressing the testosterone as well, then you don’t achieve these opposites between very high and very low levels. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: What happens is over time is the testosterone just keeps increasing and increasing and increasing, and eventually it will begin to feed the cancer, at least in theory. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So that is why we give both drugs in combination. And what happens is on a monthly basis through about twenty-eight day treatment cycles the testosterone goes from being super-high, much higher than your body would be able to make on its own back down to super-low. PAT Uh huh. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So every twenty-eight days which is roughly every four weeks, your testosterone will spike for a few days and then within about a week it will drop down to the very low levels. Patient: When you say spike, what numbers have you seen? Doctor: Right, so I told you before that a real low testosterone level for someone your age might be let’s say a hundred fifty to two hundred milligrams per deciliter. Here, they’re talking about between one thousand and one thousand five hundred milligrams per deciliter. So it’s a five- to ten-fold increase above the physiological level. So we call this super-physiological. That means higher than physiological.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Or we could not and just go straight to surgery, do the re-routing that we talked about last time – Patient: Right. Doctor: And do the study after. Either way, the comforting part is there is a potential next treatment that is – Patient: Okay. So, so how come I can’t do, do the pills and do the treatment, too? Can I do both? Doctor: No, no, no. You could the, you could do the pills. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But when you’re on pills like that, experimental ones – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You don’t want to have some big surgery, be scheduled in the middle of it. Doesn’t make sense. Because you have to do one at a time. Patient: I got you. Doctor: Because it’s a big sur – I mean it’s a big one. (Cell phone rings)

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
